user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_dma_map:
```c
int metal_dma_map(struct metal_device *dev,
		  uint32_t dir,
		  struct metal_sg *sg_in,
		  int nents_in,
		  struct metal_sg *sg_out)
{
	int nents_out;

	if (!dev || !sg_in || !sg_out)
		return -EINVAL;
	if (!dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_map)
		return -ENODEV;

	/* memory barrier */
	if (dir == METAL_DMA_DEV_R)
		/* If it is device read, apply memory write fence. */
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_release);
	else
		/* If it is device write or r/w, apply memory r/w fence. */
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_acq_rel);
	nents_out = dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_map(dev->bus,
			dev, dir, sg_in, nents_in, sg_out);
	return nents_out;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_dma_map:
struct metal_device {
	const char             *name;       /**< Device name */
	struct metal_bus       *bus;        /**< Bus that contains device */
	unsigned int           num_regions; /**< Number of I/O regions in
						 device */
	struct metal_io_region regions[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS]; /**< Array of
							I/O regions in device*/
	struct metal_list      node;       /**< Node on bus' list of devices */
	int                    irq_num;    /**< Number of IRQs per device */
	void                   *irq_info;  /**< IRQ ID */
}
...
struct metal_bus {
	const char		*name;
	struct metal_bus_ops	ops;
	struct metal_list	devices;
	struct metal_list	node;
}
...
struct metal_bus_ops {
	void		(*bus_close)(struct metal_bus *bus);
	int		(*dev_open)(struct metal_bus *bus,
				    const char *dev_name,
				    struct metal_device **device);
	void		(*dev_close)(struct metal_bus *bus,
				     struct metal_device *device);
	void		(*dev_irq_ack)(struct metal_bus *bus,
				       struct metal_device *device,
				       int irq);
	int		(*dev_dma_map)(struct metal_bus *bus,
				       struct metal_device *device,
				       uint32_t dir,
				       struct metal_sg *sg_in,
				       int nents_in,
				       struct metal_sg *sg_out);
	void		(*dev_dma_unmap)(struct metal_bus *bus,
					 struct metal_device *device,
					 uint32_t dir,
					 struct metal_sg *sg,
					 int nents);
}
...
struct metal_sg {
	void *virt; /**< CPU virtual address */
	struct metal_io_region *io; /**< IO region */
	int len; /**< length */
}
...
#define METAL_DMA_DEV_R 1
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no explicit compiler language extensions in the provided code. Specifically:
- No compiler-specific identifiers (for example __attribute__, __asm, __extension__, __builtin_*, __typeof__, __volatile__ in non-standard form, or gcc/clang-specific keywords) are present.
- No inline assembly, statement-expressions ({ ... }) used as expressions, or other known vendor extensions are used.
- The atomic_thread_fence and the memory_order_* identifiers are the standard C11 atomic facilities (stdatomic.h); these are language-standard features rather than compiler extensions. If your toolchain documents stdatomic as an extension, then those lines should be re-examined, but there is no explicit compiler-specific syntax here.
- Standard C99/C11 items such as uint32_t, function-pointer members in structs, and normal struct definitions are used; these are standard, not extensions.
- No use of zero-length arrays, flexible array members beyond standard C99, or other non-standard constructs was observed.

Therefore there are no code fragments that meet the criterion “explicitly stated as a compiler language extension” to report. If you want, I can re-evaluate for a specific compiler (e.g. older GCC, IAR, Keil) to check whether any of these standard features are documented as extensions or unsupported in that toolchain.
